answers: interest rate [accept bond yield; accept specific types of interest rates]
parts: U.S. government bonds are also known as “notes” or “securities” from this Cabinet department. This department also controls the U.S. Mint.
A bond’s duration approximately measures how its value changes as this quantity changes. The Taylor rule sets a guideline for this quantity given a country’s GDP growth rate.

The buying and selling of bonds and the setting of interest rates are two of the tools of this type of economic policy, representing the decisions made by a central bank. Unlike fiscal policy, it does not involve government legislation.

answers: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte [or Un Dimanche après-midi à l’Île de la Grande Jatte]
parts: Name this midwestern city, the most populous in Illinois. Anish Kapoor’s sculpture “Cloud Gate” is in this city’s Millenium Park
This Spanish artist’s sculpture The Sun, The Moon, and One Star is also located in Chicago. A museum dedicated to this artist of Catalan Landscape and The Tilled Field is located in Barcelona.

This large pointillist work by Georges Seurat, which mostly depicts people relaxing on the banks of the Seine, is currently housed in the Art Institute of Chicago. A woman holds an umbrella and a monkey on a leash on the right side of this painting.

answers: robots [accept Rossum’s Universal Robots; accept Three Laws of Robotics]
parts: Name this author who described the lives of characters such as the surgeon Tomas, his photographer wife Tereza, and the bowler-hat-donning artist Sabina in the novel The Unbearable Lightness of Being.
Milan Kundera’s first novel was The Joke, in which Ludvik Jahn gets in trouble for writing that this concept “is the opium of the people” on a postcard.

Karel Capek [karl chop eck], another Czech author, coined this term in his play R.U.R., which features two of the title technological entities, Marius and Sulla. Isaac Asimov wrote three laws that apply to these entities and a series named after them.

answers: The Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste [accept East Timor]
European Union [accept European Economic Community; prompt on European Community]
parts: Name this European country, where, in 1974, a regime known as the Estado Novo was overthrown by the relatively peaceful Carnation Revolution. Antonio Salazar led this country until incapacitated by a stroke in 1968.

Also in 1974, Portugal functionally abandoned this then-colony, which was promptly invaded by its neighbor. This Southeast Asian country’s current President, Francisco Guterres, is from the Fretilin party.
Portugal joined this regional organization in 1986, before this organization was officially formed by the 1992 Treaty of Maastricht. The UK officially withdrew from this organization in January 2020.
Name this neurodegenerative disease that is characterized by tremors and muscle stiffness. Neurons affected by this disease contain clumps of the protein alpha-synuclein known as Lewy bodies.

One hypothesis as to the cause of Parkinson’s disease, the Braak model, suggests that the disease progresses similarly to one caused by these agents. These misfolded proteins are also responsible for kuru and mad cow disease.

The decline in the function of this neurotransmitter and calcium ions is thought to contribute to the accumulation of Lewy bodies. This molecule is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.

answers: swans [accept “Invective Against Swans” or “The Wild Swans at Coole”]
William Butler Yeats [yates] [or W. B. Yeats]
parts: Name this American poet of “The Emperor of Ice Cream.” This poet also asked why “thin men of Haddam” were unable to see the title bird in “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.”

A Wallace Stevens poem titled “Invective Against [these birds]” describes the soul flying “beyond the parks / And far beyond the discords of the wind.” A different poet described seeing a group of these animals whose "hearts have not grown old" at Coole.

This Irish poet of “The Wild Swans at Coole” depicted the rape of Leda by Zeus in “Leda and the Swan.” This poet also described how “the falcon cannot hear the falconer” as “things fall apart; the center cannot hold” in his poem “The Second Coming.”
The goddess Idunn controls golden fruits of this type that give youth to those who consume them. In Greek mythology, the garden of the Hesperides has golden fruits of this type.
This goddess was given a golden headpiece by the Sons of Ivaldi after Loki cut off her hair. This wife of Thor has a daughter named Thrud.
A golden tree called Glasir stands in front of this location, and this place has a roof made of golden shields. In Norse myth, half of those who die in battle go to this place ruled by Odin.

answers: Newton’s second law of motion [prompt on Newton’s laws of motion]
mass moment of inertia [prompt on I; do not accept or prompt on “inertia”]
parts: Name this law, which states that the time derivative of linear momentum is equal to the net force applied. This law of classical mechanics is more commonly stated as force equals mass times acceleration.

For a rotational system, Newton’s second law states that torque is equal to the angular acceleration multiplied by this quantity. This quantity is equal to mass times distance squared for a revolving point mass.

This equation is used to find the moment of inertia for an object whose rotational axis does not go through its center of mass. A term of "m-d-squared" is added to the moment of inertia about the center of mass in this equation.

answers: insurance [accept specific types of insurance, since Geico does most of them]
parts: In a Geico ad, one of these animals asks a group of office workers to “guess what day it is.” At the end of that ad, a guitar-playing man named Ronnie says that people who save money with Geico are “happier than [one of these animals] on Wednesday.”
The Geico ad “Game night with a sloth” shows a group of people playing this game. A couple in the ad is unable to guess that a straight line is actually supposed to be a tandem bicycle.

According to Geico ads, fifteen minutes can save you fifteen percent or more on this service for cars or homes. This service, which Geico sells, is essentially a safeguard against financial loss in the event of damage.
Name this Peruvian archaeological site, a fortress and royal palace built during the reign of Pachacuti.
Machu Picchu is a city from this South American empire. This empire, centered on the city of Cuzco, fell after the conquistador Francisco Pizarro had its last emperor, Atahualpa, killed.
Atahualpa ascended to power after winning a civil war against this brother of his. This man was captured by the forces of the general Quizquiz at the Battle of Quipaipan.
Name these substances that form coordinate covalent bonds with central atoms or ions in a coordination complex. Chelation occurs when these substances attach at more than one location.
Ligands often attach to elements from this group in a coordination complex. This group of metals occupies the center of the periodic table and includes iron and silver.

Coordination complexes with four ligands often have a square planar geometry or this geometry. Molecules with sp3 [S-P-three] hybridization and no lone pairs form this geometry, which is possessed by methane.

Fire ships were used by the Dutch to destroy English warships during this event, during which Willem van Ghent and Michael de Ruyter led a daring attack on an English dockyard. The HMS Royal Charles was destroyed during this event.

During the lead up to this time period, the forces of Sun Quan and Liu Bei used fire ships to turn back the much larger force of Cao Cao at the Battle of Red Cliffs. This time period followed the collapse of the Han dynasty.
The British navy cleverly used fire ships to force this fleet sent by Philip II to break formation and scatter. This fleet was ironically referred to as the “Great and Most Fortunate Navy.”

answers: cosmic inflation [or cosmological inflation; accept inflationary epoch]
parts: Name this cosmological event in which the universe began as an extremely small region of space roughly 13.8 billion years ago.

The universe is thought to have rapidly expanded during this event, which started roughly 10 to the negative 36 seconds after the Big Bang. The isotropy and flatness of the universe is often attributed to this event.

The first epoch immediately following the creation of the universe, in which all four fundamental forces were united, is named for this German scientist. This physicist’s study of blackbodies caused him to postulate the quantization of energy.

answers: chocolate [accept Like Water for Chocolate, accept Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]
parts: Name this foodstuff that, along with water, titles a 1989 novel by Laura Esquivel. A novel titled for a manufactory of this foodstuff features the bratty Veruca Salt.
Laura Esquivel is from this country, whose native son Octavio Paz memorialized its past Aztec culture in his poem Sunstone.

Carlos Fuentes, another Mexican novelist, fictionalized the disappearance of this author in his work The Old Gringo. This author wrote a short story in which a chess-playing automaton kills its builder, “Moxon’s Master.”

Name this film starring Tippi Hedren, in which residents of Bodega Bay, California, are frequently attacked by the title creatures. This film is loosely based on a Daphne du Maurier short story with the same title.
The Birds is a film by this director of Psycho, North by Northwest, and Vertigo. This director, nicknamed “the master of suspense,” frequently cast Grace Kelly in his movies.

Hitchcock had earlier adapted Daphne du Maurier’s novel of this name into a film. In this movie, the title woman is never seen on screen, although she is discussed by Maxim de Winter and the housekeeper Mrs. Danvers.

answers: People’s Republic of China AND Republic of India [accept Zhongguo for China and Bhārat Gaṇarājya for India, do NOT accept or prompt on “Republic of China”]
parts: Name these two countries, whose disputes over territory accelerated with skirmishes at Pangong Lake. Tensions increased between these two countries when it was reported that one country’s armed forces abducted citizens at Arunachal Pradesh.
Much of the territory contested between India and China lies along large swaths of this mountain range. This mountain range contains Everest, the highest peak in the world.
In response to the skirmishes, this prime minister of India quit the Chinese social media website Weibo after the Union Government banned 59 Chinese apps for alleged security concerns.

answers: Xanadu [prompt on descriptive answers like Kubla Khan’s palace]
parts: Identify this palace described in the poem “Kubla Khan” as both a “sunny” and “stately pleasure-dome.”
This poet of “Kubla Khan” also wrote the line “water, water everywhere, nor any drop to drink,” in his long poem The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.
Coleridge worked with fellow Romantic poet William Wordsworth to publish this collection in 1798. The Rime of the Ancient Mariner and Tintern Abbey were first published in this poetry collection.

answers: Clara Josephine Wieck [or Clara Josephine Schumann; prompt on Schumann]
parts: Name this composer whose piano concerto begins with a timpani roll followed by a fortissimo tonic chord. This composer’s Peer Gynt suite contains a short section depicting trolls, “In the Hall of the Mountain King.”

Grieg’s piano concerto is in this note’s minor key, which has no sharps or flats and is the relative minor of C major. The concerto was inspired by Robert Schumann’s piano concerto which is also in this minor key.

Grieg first heard Robert Schumann’s piano concerto being performed by this pianist and composer of three Romances for Violin and Piano. Along with Robert Schumann, this composer advised and premiered many of Johannes Brahms’s piano works.

answers: mass suicide [accept equivalents; prompt on descriptions of death]
parts: Name these objects which are any aerial vehicle whose origin is unknown. Conspiracy theorists often attribute sightings of these objects to alien spacecraft visiting Earth.

39 followers of the UFO religion Heaven’s Gate undertook this action in 1997 in order to board a UFO that they believed was trailing the Hale-Bopp comet. Members of the People’s Temple were ordered to take this action in Jonestown, Guyana in 1978.

A more well-known UFO religion, the Nation of Islam, rose to prominence under the leadership of this man. This man established the Nation’s belief in a “Mother Plane,” a UFO that visited the prophet Ezekiel.

James Wilkinson worked under Horatio Gates, who this group chose to replace George Washington as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army. Wilkinson later helped force the resignation of this group’s namesake by providing Washington with incriminating evidence.

As Governor of the Louisiana Territory, Wilkinson later partnered with this man to plan the formation of a new country in the Southwest U.S. An electoral deadlock involving this non-Virginian politician led to the passage of the Twelfth Amendment.

While a captain in the Continental Army, Wilkinson led reinforcements to Quebec to support this besieging general. Later, this famed traitor’s plan to hand over West Point to the British was foiled by the capture of his associate John Andre.
